DADOS-GERAIS.NOME-EM-CITACOES-BIBLIOGRAFICAS: MARTINELLI, A. H. S.;MARTINELLI, A.H.;Martinelli, Anne H.S.;MARTINELLI, ANNE HELENE SOUZA;MARTINELLI, ANNE HELENE S.;MARTINELLI, ANNE

RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH: Possui graduao em Cincias Biolgicas pela Universidade do Vale do Rio dos Sinos (2004), Mestrado (2007) e Doutorado (2012) em Biologia Celular e Molecular pela Universidade Federal do Rio Grande do Sul. Atua como tcnica na Universidade Federal do Rio Grande do Sul, participando em aulas prticas dos cursos de graduao (Cincias Biolgicas, Biomedicina, Enfermagem, Veterinria, Zoologia e Nutrio) e como pesquisadora colaboradora, nesta mesma Universidade. Possui experincia na rea de Biologia Molecular; Biofsica e Bioqumica de protenas; Microbiologia; Clonagem, Expresso e Purificao de Protenas Recombinantes; Mecanismos de ao de Peptdeos Fungitxicos e Inseticidas.
RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH-EN: graduate at Cincias Biolgicas from Universidade do Vale do Rio dos Sinos (2004) and master's at General Biology from Universidade Federal do Rio Grande do Sul (2007). , acting on the following subjects: amilase, aspergillus niger, fermentao, urease and tabaco.

ENDERECO-PROFISSIONAL.NOME-INSTITUICAO-EMPRESA: Universidade Federal do Rio Grande do Sul

ATUACAO-PROFISSIONAL.NOME-INSTITUICAO: Universidade Federal do Rio Grande do Sul

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Ureases: aspectos estruturais e propriedades biolgicas
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: Ureases hidrolisam uria a amnia e CO2. Isoformas de urease tm alta homologia, mas certas atividades biolgicas so prprias de uma isoforma em particular. Por anlises cromatogrficas, eletroforticas, espectroscpicas, cristalografia, modelagem molecular, estudamos relaes estrutura X atividade biolgica de ureases de plantas (Canavalia ensiformis; Glycine max; Gossypium hirsutum); bacterias (Helicobacter pylori, Bradyrhizobium sp., Bacillus pasteurii)e do fungo Cryptococcus neoformans.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: Ureases hidrolisam uria a amnia e CO2. Isoformas de urease tm alta homologia, mas certas atividades biolgicas so prprias de uma isoforma em particular. Por anlises cromatogrficas, eletroforticas, espectroscpicas, cristalografia, modelagem molecular, estudamos relaes estrutura X atividade biolgica de ureases de plantas (Canavalia ensiformis; Glycine max; Gossypium hirsutum); bacterias (Helicobacter pylori, Bradyrhizobium sp., Bacillus pasteurii)e do fungo Cryptococcus neoformans.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: Ureases: aspectos estruturais e propriedades biolgicas

INTEGRANTES-DO-PROJETO.NOME-PARA-CITACAO: MARTINELLI, A. H. S.;MARTINELLI, A.H.;Martinelli, Anne H.S.;MARTINELLI, ANNE HELENE SOUZA;MARTINELLI, ANNE HELENE S.;MARTINELLI, ANNE

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: 4.Protenas Txicas e Ureases em Sementes de Soja (Glycine max)
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: Os estudos visam isolamento, caracterizao fsico-qumica de ureases e protenas relacionadas (ex: soyatoxina, soybean toxin), clonagem de genes de ureases e de protenas acessrias que incorporam Ni nas ureases. Estudos de ativao de apoureases heterlogas e da eficincia de nodulao de soja por Bradyrhizobium japonicum mutantes para genes de ureases.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: Os estudos visam isolamento, caracterizao fsico-qumica de ureases e protenas relacionadas (ex: soyatoxina, soybean toxin), clonagem de genes de ureases e de protenas acessrias que incorporam Ni nas ureases. Estudos de ativao de apoureases heterlogas e da eficincia de nodulao de soja por Bradyrhizobium japonicum mutantes para genes de ureases.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: 4.Protenas Txicas e Ureases em Sementes de Soja (Glycine max)

AUTORES.NOME-PARA-CITACAO: MARTINELLI, A. H. S.;MARTINELLI, A.H.;Martinelli, Anne H.S.;MARTINELLI, ANNE HELENE SOUZA;MARTINELLI, ANNE HELENE S.;MARTINELLI, ANNE

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Enzymatic detergent formulation containing amylase from Aspergillus niger: A comparative study with commercial detergent formulations
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO-INGLES: Enzymatic detergent formulation containing amylase from Aspergillus niger: A comparative study with commercial detergent formulations

AUTORES.NOME-PARA-CITACAO: MARTINELLI, A. H. S.;MARTINELLI, A.H.;Martinelli, Anne H.S.;MARTINELLI, ANNE HELENE SOUZA;MARTINELLI, ANNE HELENE S.;MARTINELLI, ANNE

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: There is a wide range of biotechnological applications for amylases, including the textile, pharmaceutical, food and laundry industries. Hydrolytic enzymes are 100% biodegradable and enzymatic detergents can achieve effective cleaning with lukewarm water. Microorganisms and culture media were tested for amylase production and the best producer was Aspergillus niger L119 (3.9 U ml−1 0.2) in submerged culture and its amylase demonstrated excellent activity at 50?55 C and pH 4.0, remaining stable at 53 C for up to 200 h. In order to establish the potential uses of this enzyme in detergents, different formulations were tested using the A. niger amylase extract. Enzyme activity was compared with three commercial formulations. The detergents are used in hospitals to clean surgical and endoscopy equipment. The presence of amylase in the formulation is because of its action within hospital drainage system, whether or not it has any function in cleaning the equipment.
INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES: There is a wide range of biotechnological applications for amylases, including the textile, pharmaceutical, food and laundry industries. Hydrolytic enzymes are 100% biodegradable and enzymatic detergents can achieve effective cleaning with lukewarm water. Microorganisms and culture media were tested for amylase production and the best producer was Aspergillus niger L119 (3.9 U ml−1 0.2) in submerged culture and its amylase demonstrated excellent activity at 50?55 C and pH 4.0, remaining stable at 53 C for up to 200 h. In order to establish the potential uses of this enzyme in detergents, different formulations were tested using the A. niger amylase extract. Enzyme activity was compared with three commercial formulations. The detergents are used in hospitals to clean surgical and endoscopy equipment. The presence of amylase in the formulation is because of its action within hospital drainage system, whether or not it has any function in cleaning the equipment.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Urease from Cotton (Gossypium hirsutum) Seeds: Isolation, Physicochemical Characterization, and Antifungal Properties of the Protein
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO-INGLES: Urease from Cotton (Gossypium hirsutum) Seeds: Isolation, Physicochemical Characterization, and Antifungal Properties of the Protein

DETALHAMENTO-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-PERIODICO-OU-REVISTA: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry

AUTORES.NOME-PARA-CITACAO: MARTINELLI, A. H. S.;MARTINELLI, A.H.;Martinelli, Anne H.S.;MARTINELLI, ANNE HELENE SOUZA;MARTINELLI, ANNE HELENE S.;MARTINELLI, ANNE

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Ureases (EC 3.5.1.5) are metalloenzymes that hydrolyze urea to produce ammonia and carbon dioxide These enzymes, which are found in fungi, bacteria, and plants, show very similar structures. Despite an abundance of urease in vegetal tissues, the physiological role of this enzyme in plants is still poorly understood. It has been previously described that ureases from the legumes jackbean (Canavalia ensiformis) and soybean (Glycine max) have insecticidal activity and antifungal properties. This work presents the physicochemical purification and characterization of a urease from cotton (Gossypium hirsutum) seeds, the first description of this enzyme in Malvaceae. The urease content varied among different cotton cultivars. Cotton seed urease (98.3 kDa) displayed low ureolytic activity but exhibited potent antifungal properties at sub-micromolar concentrations against different phytopathogenic fungi. As described for other ureases, the antifungal effect of cotton urease persisted after treatment with an irreversible inhibitor of its enzyme activity. The data suggest an important role of these proteins in plant defense.
INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES: Ureases (EC 3.5.1.5) are metalloenzymes that hydrolyze urea to produce ammonia and carbon dioxide These enzymes, which are found in fungi, bacteria, and plants, show very similar structures. Despite an abundance of urease in vegetal tissues, the physiological role of this enzyme in plants is still poorly understood. It has been previously described that ureases from the legumes jackbean (Canavalia ensiformis) and soybean (Glycine max) have insecticidal activity and antifungal properties. This work presents the physicochemical purification and characterization of a urease from cotton (Gossypium hirsutum) seeds, the first description of this enzyme in Malvaceae. The urease content varied among different cotton cultivars. Cotton seed urease (98.3 kDa) displayed low ureolytic activity but exhibited potent antifungal properties at sub-micromolar concentrations against different phytopathogenic fungi. As described for other ureases, the antifungal effect of cotton urease persisted after treatment with an irreversible inhibitor of its enzyme activity. The data suggest an important role of these proteins in plant defense.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Antifungal activity of plant and bacterial ureases?
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO-INGLES: Antifungal activity of plant and bacterial ureases?

AUTORES.NOME-PARA-CITACAO: MARTINELLI, A. H. S.;MARTINELLI, A.H.;Martinelli, Anne H.S.;MARTINELLI, ANNE HELENE SOUZA;MARTINELLI, ANNE HELENE S.;MARTINELLI, ANNE

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Ureases (EC 3.5.1.5) are nickel-dependent metalloenzymes that catalyze the hydrolysis of urea to ammonia and carbon dioxide. Produced by plants, fungi and bacteria, but not by animals, ureases share significant homology and similar mechanisms of catalysis, although differing in quaternary structures. While fungal and plant ureases are homo-oligomeric proteins of 90 kDa subunits, bacterial ureases are multimers of two (e.g. Helicobacter pylori) or three subunit complexes. It has been proposed that in plants these enzymes are involved in nitrogen bioavailability and in protection against pathogens. Previous studies by our group have shown that plant ureases, but not a bacterial (Bacillus pasteurii) urease, display insecticidal activity. Herein we demonstrate that (Glycine max) embryo-specific soybean urease, jackbean (Canavalia ensiformis) major urease and a recombinant H. pylori urease impair growth of selected phytopathogenic fungi at sub-micromolar concentrations. This antifungal property of ureases is not affected by treatment of the proteins with an irreversible inhibitor of the ureolytic activity. Scanning electron microscopy of urease-treated fungi suggests plasmolysis and cell wall injuries. Altogether, our data indicate that ureases probably contribute to the plant arsenal of defense compounds against predators and phytopathogens and that the urease defense mechanism is independent of ammonia release from urea.
INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES: Ureases (EC 3.5.1.5) are nickel-dependent metalloenzymes that catalyze the hydrolysis of urea to ammonia and carbon dioxide. Produced by plants, fungi and bacteria, but not by animals, ureases share significant homology and similar mechanisms of catalysis, although differing in quaternary structures. While fungal and plant ureases are homo-oligomeric proteins of 90 kDa subunits, bacterial ureases are multimers of two (e.g. Helicobacter pylori) or three subunit complexes. It has been proposed that in plants these enzymes are involved in nitrogen bioavailability and in protection against pathogens. Previous studies by our group have shown that plant ureases, but not a bacterial (Bacillus pasteurii) urease, display insecticidal activity. Herein we demonstrate that (Glycine max) embryo-specific soybean urease, jackbean (Canavalia ensiformis) major urease and a recombinant H. pylori urease impair growth of selected phytopathogenic fungi at sub-micromolar concentrations. This antifungal property of ureases is not affected by treatment of the proteins with an irreversible inhibitor of the ureolytic activity. Scanning electron microscopy of urease-treated fungi suggests plasmolysis and cell wall injuries. Altogether, our data indicate that ureases probably contribute to the plant arsenal of defense compounds against predators and phytopathogens and that the urease defense mechanism is independent of ammonia release from urea.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Ubiquitous urease affects soybean susceptibility to fungi
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO-INGLES: Ubiquitous urease affects soybean susceptibility to fungi

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: The soybean ubiquitous urease (encoded by GmEu4) is responsible for recycling metabolically derived urea. Additional biological roles have been demonstrated for plant ureases, notably in toxicity to other organisms. However, urease enzymatic activity is not related to its toxicity. The role of GmEu4 in soybean susceptibility to fungi was investigated in this study. A differential expression pattern of GmEu4 was observed in susceptible and resistant genotypes of soybeans over the course of a Phakopsora pachyrhizi infection, especially 24 h afterinfection. Twenty-nine adult, transgenic soybean plants, representing six independently transformed lines, were obtained. Although the initial aim of this study was to overexpress GmEu4, the transgenic plants exhibited GmEu4 co-suppression and decreased ureolytic activity. The growth of Rhizoctonia solani, Phomopsis sp., and Penicillium herguei in media containing a crude protein extract from either transgenic or non-transgenic leaves was evaluated. The fungal growth was higher in the protein extracts from transgenic urease-deprived plants than in extracts from nontransgenic controls. When infected by P. pachyrhizi uredospores, detached leaves of urease-deprived plants developed a signiﬁcantly higher number of lesions, pustules and erupted pustules than leaves of non-transgenic plants containing normal levels of the enzyme. The results of the present work show that the soybean plants were more susceptible to fungi in the absence of urease. It was not possible to overexpress active GmEu4. For future work, overexpression of urease fungitoxic peptides could be attempted as an alternative approach.
INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES: The soybean ubiquitous urease (encoded by GmEu4) is responsible for recycling metabolically derived urea. Additional biological roles have been demonstrated for plant ureases, notably in toxicity to other organisms. However, urease enzymatic activity is not related to its toxicity. The role of GmEu4 in soybean susceptibility to fungi was investigated in this study. A differential expression pattern of GmEu4 was observed in susceptible and resistant genotypes of soybeans over the course of a Phakopsora pachyrhizi infection, especially 24 h afterinfection. Twenty-nine adult, transgenic soybean plants, representing six independently transformed lines, were obtained. Although the initial aim of this study was to overexpress GmEu4, the transgenic plants exhibited GmEu4 co-suppression and decreased ureolytic activity. The growth of Rhizoctonia solani, Phomopsis sp., and Penicillium herguei in media containing a crude protein extract from either transgenic or non-transgenic leaves was evaluated. The fungal growth was higher in the protein extracts from transgenic urease-deprived plants than in extracts from nontransgenic controls. When infected by P. pachyrhizi uredospores, detached leaves of urease-deprived plants developed a signiﬁcantly higher number of lesions, pustules and erupted pustules than leaves of non-transgenic plants containing normal levels of the enzyme. The results of the present work show that the soybean plants were more susceptible to fungi in the absence of urease. It was not possible to overexpress active GmEu4. For future work, overexpression of urease fungitoxic peptides could be attempted as an alternative approach.
